item.title: Literary Movements
item.description: Old English 450-1066 Middle English 1066-1500 The Renaissance 1500-1660 The Elizabethan Age 1558-1603 The Jacobean Age 1603-1625 The Restoration Period 1660-1700

item.title: Allen Ginsberg
item.description: Beat Generation Poet Counterculture Openly gay Known for raw - grotesque - unrefined - gritty poetry meant to be heard, not read

item.title: anaphora
item.description: In rhetoric, an anaphora (Greek, “carrying back”) is a rhetorical device that consists of repeating a sequence of words at the beginnings of neighboring clauses for emphasis

item.title: John Lennon
item.description: Part of The Beatles Married Yoko Ono

item.title: Mark Twain
item.description: Mark Twain ![[images/Pasted image 20230410035635.png|100]] born Samuel Langhorne Clemens writer - satirist - one of the greatest American writers and the father of American literature

item.title: Symbols, Motifs, and Themes
item.description: Symbols, motifs, and themes are often confused with each other. Though they share similarities, they are vastly different. Themes are abstract ideas Motifs are more concrete and appear in the text multiple times Symbols are also more concrete, but unlike motifs, they do not reappear.

item.title: Character of Dogs
item.description: Character of Dogs By [[Robert Louis Stevenson]] Full Text THE CHARACTER OF DOGS The civilisation, the manners, and the morals 1 of dog-kind are to a great extent subordinated to those of his ancestral master, man.

item.title: Robert Louis Stevenson
item.description: Quotes â€œThe difficulty of literature is not to write, but to write what you mean; not to affect your reader, but to affect him precisely as you wish.

item.title: America by Allen Ginsberg
George Bernard Shaw
item.description: Playwright Born in Dublin Grew up in poverty Dad was alcoholic

item.title: Pygmalion
item.description: Pygmalion Play Written by [[George Bernard Shaw]] in 1912 ![[inbox/unprocessed/Victorian Era]] Title is based on Greek mythology Pygamlion - a sculptor; makes an ivory statue representing ideal womanhood; falls in love w his own creation, names her Galatea; prays and gets the statue brought to life

item.title: Virginia Woolf
item.description: ![[images/woolf.jpg|100]] Feminist Modernist writer pioneer in use of [[Stream of Consciousness]] as a narrative device Part of Bloomsbury Group husband Leonard Woolf | started Hogarth Press w Leonard Woolf Most famous works - novels - Mrs Dalloway and To the Lighthouse

item.title: WB Yeats
item.description: Irish poet - Irish Nationalist Symbolist Inspired by Pre-Raphaelites and William Blake poetry was a reaction to the naturalistic and realistic poetry of the Victorian age
